accomplishments:
Implemented needed roles for improved, scalable customer success - full time CSMs, domain SMEs, CS Ops. 
5 CSMs hired, 2 let go, 100% of accounts covered with 175%/300% current team as billable. Transitioned role collateral from geared to volunteer CLs to professionals spanning multiple accounts. 
2 domain SMEs hired after 2 accounts that could benefit identified. 
Hired Ops Manager with agreement to share with Growth to fully leverage our systems and data as it becomes a company imperative. 
All hires came by way of referrals.




Major focus on proactively identifying risks and working mitigations - experimented with different types of reporting, health scoring, and intervention mechanisms. Partnered across other departments including reshaping needs as fundamental roles shifted from PL to DL occurred.




Improved leadership awareness of account health and alignment towards renewal activities - iterative quarterly Account Health Score refinement, Account Strategy documentation and sessions, stakeholder mapping, Customer Fit Scoring implementation, and refined async account comms

**Carlo Viray:**
Ever since you joined Rise8 I’ve been super thankful and appreciative of everything you’ve done. You’ve brought so much structure, thoughtfulness, and maturity to how we operate, both internally and with clients. You’ve been absolutely crushing it, even though renewals haven’t gone the way we hoped (a lot of that has been outside your control or influence also)




Working with you is always easy and enjoyable. You’re direct, dependable, and someone I genuinely like partnering with. I trust you, and I know that when you say you’ll handle something, you will.




The constructive feedback I have is really more about what I’ve observed from afar as we all try to figure out the new structure between you, Adam, and Max. Right now I’m struggling to understand what Customer Success and Delivery look like together moving forward. I know you two are still defining it, but from my side, the biggest area where I need clarity is around handoffs from contract award, customer engagement, and ongoing follow-up.




The Greiser “homework assignments” situation was rough for me because you asked whether I should take ownership, and I didn’t have the context for that conversation at all. It put me in a weird spot because I didn’t know what the expectations were or how to respond. And that ties into the broader pattern we keep hitting across leadership where we’re all stepping into situations and asking, “Wait, who owns this?” It came up again with the FORGE licenses and funding comms, not necessarily your fault, but it highlights the lack of clarity we’re all running into. I don’t know the solution yet, but I want to call out the pattern because it’s something we’re consistently bumping into.

**Jeff Muller:**
A ton of progress in 2025 developing our CS function, especially as we were able to bring on dedicated CSMs.

**Riya Patel:**
I love working with Kristin. I'll save some commentary for the next question but one thing I especially appreciate about Kristin is how she communicates the bigger picture and provides the CSMs a more real time picture of what is going on in the company and what to expect. I never feel caught off guard by a company decision or announcement, because Kristin is really good about communicating ahead of time and it reduces a lot of churn and confusion.

**Sharon Hamilton:**
Kristen is the personification of an A player. She models a growth mindset for her team and when the Customer Success team encounters a difficult challenge she doesn't complain; she immediately initiates a process to develop new team abilities, intelligence, or operational playbooks to ensure they can handle similar challenges successfully in the future. She empowers her team to make critical decisions without unnecessary layers of bureaucracy. She actively resists implementing rigid, unnecessary rules that would slow down timely team support and customer success efforts.Kristen keeps it real with her team and leadership regarding the true state of customer health, outcomes, and leading indicators. She quickly identifies opportunities for pivots, and she takes full ownership of all results without making excuses or shifting blame to other departments. She consistently challenges her teammates and peers directly on performance or strategy while delivering high-quality, actionable feedback. Her approach is balanced, ensuring the recipient always knows their development and well-being are cared for. Kristen is an exemplar of integrity, always ensuring that the team's actions and recommendations are what is right by the customer (even if it's challenging internally), the team, and the company.

**Max Reele:**
Kristin is a top professional at healthily managing team dynamics, organizing across departments, and breaking down complex problems for driving step-by-step plans for solutions.

**Rachel Del Vecchio:**
From what I've witnessed in a cross-department, KP does an amazing job providing context and thoughtfulness on behalf of the customer and customer experience.

**Bryon Kroger:**
On "challenges directly and provides quality feedback without making others feel like they aren’t cared for" I've seen some instances, especially lately, where you don't challenge things directly and instead either avoid the issue or take more of a passive or indirect approach. In a couple cases the passive approach, because you also tend to be fairly aggressive (in a good way), comes out in a way that is passive aggressive and frustrating to your peers. I've not had it happen with me, so I recommend checking in with your peers on it. I'm also not sure I can pinpoint why, and this is something I really only started to see this year, especially recently.
